summary: a computer was used to screen 10,000 chemicals in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) [1], leading to the identification of a haloperidol analog capable of inhibiting HIV-1 and HIV-2 proteases with a K i of 100 M. the screening was accomplished using a computer docking program, DOCK, that docked each chemical of the database into the active sites of the enzymes. the program was devised to search for the specific conformations, positions, and orientations a sustained petaflops capability would be able to screen 23 million chemicals in about 10 minutes or to screen 2005000 billion chemicals for one drug target in a year. this capability offers the possibility of identifying inhibitors that are effective enough for in vivo testing. we seek to extend the application of the EUDOC program to supramolecular chemistry. the average interaction energy of these small-molecule complexes (50.1 kcal/mol) is nearly half that of the 153 small molecule-bound protein complexes we studied in previous tests (108.5 kcal/mol) the results also demonstrate the significant influence of crystal packing on small-molecule complex crystal structures. a total of 161 crystal structures of small-molecule guest-host complexes were obtained from CSD for this study. the results of the docking studies with the 161 complexes using the procedure described above are listed in Table 1. EUDOC identified one alternative binding mode that is energetically indistinguishable from the binding mode of the crystal structure. 31 (19%) of the 161 complexes could not be accurately reproduced with mwRMSDs of 1.0 if neighboring structures were not included. only 2 (1%) of these complexes could not be accurately reproduced with mwRMSDs of 1.0 if neighboring structures were excluded from the host system. study suggests that crystal packing should be taken into account when reproducing crystal structures of small-molecule guest-host complexes. water molecules, counterions or other companying molecules such as ethanol can be excluded from the host system. success rate of docking a small molecule into another small molecule is about 93% if the influence of crystal packing is ignored. the crystal structure of complex YAWJIP was proposed to have face-to-face -stacking with the acridine portion of Rebek's acridine diacids. but the face-to-face -stacking was found in neither the crystal structure of complex YAWJIP [15] nor the Monte Carlo statistical mechanics calculations of the complex [16]. 154 reported crystal structures of proteins in complex with small molecules [3] and the 161 crystal structures of guest-host complexes reported herein suggested that the noncovalent interactions of the guest-host complexes are in general weaker than those of the protein complexes. this confirmation suggests that to design high-affinity guest-host complexes it is of advantage to incorporate the entropic energy into the binding, because the number of functional groups that can be introduced onto the guest and host structures is limited by the size mwRMSDs of 1.0 if neighboring structures were included but water molecules were excluded from the host system. this is consistent with our reported finding that complexation between a small molecule and a protein is not commonly mediated by water molecules. this study suggests that crystal packing should be taken into account when reproducing crystal structures of small-molecule guest-host complexes. crystal structure of complex YAWJIP was proposed to have face-to-face -stacking with the acridine portion of Rebek's acridine diacids. but the face-to-face -stacking was found in neither the crystal structure of complex YAWJIP [15] nor the Monte Carlo statistical mechanics calculations of the complex. the EUDOC program generated a complex nearly identical to the crystal structure of form A. but not the proposed complex with nearly face-to-face -stacking. it suggests that the noncovalent interactions of the guest-host complexes are weaker than those of the protein complexes. molecules, counterions, and solvent molecules such as ethanol were removed from the guest or host structure. hydrogen atoms were added using the QUANTA97 program (Accelrys Software, Inc, San Diego, California) followed by energy minimization of the hydrogen atoms using the second-generation AMBER force field (parm99.dat) [17] and a positional constraint on all non-hydrogen atoms. the size of the docking box and the cutoff for the interaction energy used by the EUDOC program are listed in Table S2 of Supporting Information. the complex-prediction module of the EUDOC program was used to translate and rotate the guest around the host at increments of 1.0 and 10° of arc. the atomic charges of the guest and host structures listed in Table S1 of Supporting Information were determined according to pKa values of functional groups at pH of 7.0. the atomic charges of the guest and host structures listed in Table S1 of Supporting Information were determined according to pKa values of functional groups at pH of 7.0. the intermolecular interaction energy is the potential energy of the guest-host complex relative to the potential energies of the two partners in their free state. a docking box was defined to enclose the guest structure in the crystal structure of the guest-host complex. the distance cutoffs for steric and electrostatic interactions were set to 109. NMODE analysis was performed with the NMODE module of AMBER8 [19] using (1) ilevel = 0 or 1, (2) cut = 12, (3) scnb = 2.0, (3) scee = 1.2, (5) dielc = 80, and (6) idiel = 1. Mass-weighted root mean square deviations The mwRMSDs were calculated by superimposing the host portion of the EUDOC-generated complex over the corresponding host portion of the crystal structure followed by Figure S6 Chemical structures of the 161 host-guest complexes.
